title: Demi Moore bombed audition for Top Gun role opposite Tom Cruise: 'I didn't think I was good enough'
text:
She embarked on a media blitz for her new memoir Inside Out just weeks ago.

And Demi Moore stopped by the new Sirius/XM studios in Los Angeles on Wednesday afternoon for a catch-up with radio legend Howard Stern as he set up shop to usher in the new West Coast location.

The 56-year-old actress got cozy on the couch and revealed to the King of All Media that her illustrious career certainly had some set backs, like the time she lost out on a starring role opposite Tom Cruise in Top Gun.

'I think it was just the timing of things,' she told Stern. 'I think the first audition was great and the screen test ... I shanked ... I got in my head.'

Kelly McGillis ultimately landed the role as Charlotte 'Charlie' Blackwood, a civilian instructor at the fighter pilot training school within the Naval Fighter Weapons School at Naval Air Station Miramar.

'I think I just got nervous of the whole and I didn't own it,' she admitted.

Demi still saw the film, which was released in 1986 and also starred Val Kilmer, Anthony Edwards and Tom Skerritt.

'I could have really done that one,' she said. 'But in my beating myself up, it then just reinforced the idea that I didn't think I was good enough.'

A few short years after her failed attempt at earning a spot on the Tony Scott film, Demi starred opposite Patrick Swayze in Ghost, a movie she was surprised to see garner bad reviews.

'I was so shocked because I had watched it, I was with other people and we all had the same feeling. I thought it was really great,' she said

'I was so shocked because I had watched it, I was with other people and we all had the same feeling. I thought it was really great,' she said. 'I must really be missing something, what are they seeing that I'm not? There were too many people, smart people, who felt the same way I did.'

The lighthearted discussion was a welcome to the difficult stories in her new book where Demi admitted she was raped at the age of 15 by a much older man.

'I felt trapped, I didn't want and I was clear that I didn't,' she told Stern. 'I felt like it was my fault. I felt like I had behaved in a way that was mature, like I really knew a lot.

'I never really looked at myself as being a kid. I never looked at it as rape. I saw it as unfortunate, I was very embarrassed by it.'
